00092 /** This utility routine copies the metadata (if any) attached to the
00093     'from' instruction in the IR to the 'to' instruction.  
00094 
00095     For flexibility, this function takes an llvm::Value rather than an
00096     llvm::Instruction for the 'to' parameter; at some places in the code
00097     below, we sometimes use a llvm::Value to start out storing a value and
00098     then later store instructions.  If a llvm::Value is passed to this, the
00099     routine just returns without doing anything; if it is in fact an
00100     LLVM::Instruction, then the metadata can be copied to it.
00101  */
00102 static void
00103 lCopyMetadata(llvm::Value *vto, const llvm::Instruction *from) {
00104     llvm::Instruction *to = llvm::dyn_cast<llvm::Instruction>(vto);
00105     if (!to) 
00106         return;
00107                                                               
00108     llvm::SmallVector<std::pair<unsigned int, llvm::MDNode *>, 8> metadata;
00109     from->getAllMetadata(metadata);
00110     for (unsigned int i = 0; i < metadata.size(); ++i)
00111         to->setMetadata(metadata[i].first, metadata[i].second);
00112 }

00114 
00115 /** We have a protocol with the front-end LLVM IR code generation process
00116     that allows us to encode the source file position that corresponds with
00117     instructions.  (For example, this allows us to issue performance
00118     warnings related to things like scatter and gather after optimization
00119     has been performed, so that we aren't warning about scatters and
00120     gathers that have been improved to stores and loads by optimization
00121     passes.)  Note that this is slightly redundant with the source file
00122     position encoding generated for debugging symbols, though we don't
00123     always generate debugging information but we do always generate this
00124     position data.
00125 
00126     This function finds the SourcePos that the metadata in the instruction
00127     (if present) corresponds to.  See the implementation of
00128     FunctionEmitContext::addGSMetadata(), which encodes the source position during
00129     code generation.
00130 
00131     @param inst   Instruction to try to find the source position of
00132     @param pos    Output variable in which to store the position
00133     @returns      True if source file position metadata was present and *pos
00134                   has been set.  False otherwise.
00135 */
00136 static bool
00137 lGetSourcePosFromMetadata(const llvm::Instruction *inst, SourcePos *pos) {
00138     llvm::MDNode *filename = inst->getMetadata("filename");
00139     llvm::MDNode *line = inst->getMetadata("line");
00140     llvm::MDNode *column = inst->getMetadata("column");
00141     if (!filename || !line || !column)
00142         return false;
00143 
00144     // All of these asserts are things that FunctionEmitContext::addGSMetadata() is
00145     // expected to have done in its operation
00146     assert(filename->getNumOperands() == 1 && line->getNumOperands() == 1);
00147     llvm::MDString *str = llvm::dyn_cast<llvm::MDString>(filename->getOperand(0));
00148     assert(str);
00149     llvm::ConstantInt *lnum = llvm::dyn_cast<llvm::ConstantInt>(line->getOperand(0));
00150     assert(lnum);
00151     llvm::ConstantInt *colnum = llvm::dyn_cast<llvm::ConstantInt>(column->getOperand(0));
00152     assert(column);
00153 
00154     *pos = SourcePos(str->getString().data(), (int)lnum->getZExtValue(),
00155                    (int)colnum->getZExtValue());
00156     return true;
00157 }

00160 /** Utility routine that prints out the LLVM IR for everything in the
00161     module.  (Used for debugging).
00162  */
00163 static void
00164 lPrintModuleCode(llvm::Module *module) {
00165     llvm::PassManager ppm;
00166     ppm.add(llvm::createPrintModulePass(&llvm::outs()));
00167     ppm.run(*module);
00168 }

00170 
00171 void
00172 Optimize(llvm::Module *module, int optLevel) {
00173     if (g->debugPrint) {
00174         printf("*** Code going into optimization ***\n");
00175         lPrintModuleCode(module);
00176     }
00177 
00178     llvm::PassManager optPM;
00179     llvm::FunctionPassManager funcPM(module);
00180 
00181 #ifndef LLVM_2_8
00182     llvm::TargetLibraryInfo *targetLibraryInfo =
00183         new llvm::TargetLibraryInfo(llvm::Triple(module->getTargetTriple()));
00184     optPM.add(targetLibraryInfo);
00185 #endif
00186     optPM.add(new llvm::TargetData(module));
00187 
00188     if (optLevel == 0) {
00189         // This is more or less the minimum set of optimizations that we
00190         // need to do to generate code that will actually run.  (We can't
00191         // run absolutely no optimizations, since the front-end needs us to
00192         // take the various __pseudo_* functions it has emitted and turn
00193         // them into something that can actually execute.
00194         optPM.add(CreateGatherScatterFlattenPass());
00195         optPM.add(CreateLowerGatherScatterPass());
00196         optPM.add(CreateLowerMaskedStorePass());
00197         optPM.add(CreateIsCompileTimeConstantPass(true));
00198         optPM.add(llvm::createFunctionInliningPass());
00199         optPM.add(CreateMakeInternalFuncsStaticPass());
00200         optPM.add(llvm::createGlobalDCEPass());
00201     }
00202     else {
00203         // Otherwise throw the kitchen sink of optimizations at the code.
00204         // This is almost certainly overkill and likely could be reduced,
00205         // but on the other hand trying to remove some of these has
00206         // historically caused performance slowdowns.  Benchmark carefully
00207         // if changing these around.
00208         //
00209         // Note in particular that a number of the ispc optimization
00210         // passes are run repeatedly along the way; they often can kick in
00211         // only later in the optimization process as things like constant
00212         // propagation have done their thing, and then when they do kick
00213         // in, they can often open up new opportunities for optimization...
00214 #ifndef LLVM_2_8
00215         llvm::PassRegistry *registry = llvm::PassRegistry::getPassRegistry();
00216         llvm::initializeCore(*registry);
00217         llvm::initializeScalarOpts(*registry);
00218         llvm::initializeIPO(*registry);
00219         llvm::initializeAnalysis(*registry);
00220         llvm::initializeIPA(*registry);
00221         llvm::initializeTransformUtils(*registry);
00222         llvm::initializeInstCombine(*registry);
00223         llvm::initializeInstrumentation(*registry);
00224         llvm::initializeTarget(*registry);
00225 #endif
00226         // Early optimizations to try to reduce the total amount of code to
00227         // work with if we can
00228         optPM.add(CreateGatherScatterFlattenPass());
00229         optPM.add(llvm::createReassociatePass());
00230         optPM.add(llvm::createConstantPropagationPass());
00231 
00232         if (!g->opt.disableMaskedStoreOptimizations) {
00233             optPM.add(CreateIntrinsicsOptPass());
00234             optPM.add(CreateMaskedStoreOptPass());
00235         }
00236         optPM.add(llvm::createDeadInstEliminationPass());
00237 
00238         optPM.add(llvm::createConstantPropagationPass());
00239         optPM.add(llvm::createDeadInstEliminationPass());
00240         
00241         // On to more serious optimizations
00242         optPM.add(llvm::createCFGSimplificationPass());
00243         optPM.add(llvm::createScalarReplAggregatesPass());
00244         optPM.add(llvm::createInstructionCombiningPass());
00245         optPM.add(llvm::createCFGSimplificationPass());
00246         optPM.add(llvm::createPromoteMemoryToRegisterPass());
00247         optPM.add(llvm::createGlobalOptimizerPass());
00248         optPM.add(llvm::createReassociatePass());
00249         optPM.add(llvm::createIPConstantPropagationPass());
00250         optPM.add(llvm::createDeadArgEliminationPass());
00251         optPM.add(llvm::createInstructionCombiningPass());
00252         optPM.add(llvm::createCFGSimplificationPass());
00253         optPM.add(llvm::createPruneEHPass());
00254         optPM.add(llvm::createFunctionAttrsPass());
00255         optPM.add(llvm::createFunctionInliningPass());
00256         optPM.add(llvm::createConstantPropagationPass());
00257         optPM.add(llvm::createDeadInstEliminationPass());
00258         optPM.add(llvm::createCFGSimplificationPass());
00259 
00260         optPM.add(llvm::createArgumentPromotionPass());
00261         optPM.add(llvm::createSimplifyLibCallsPass());
00262         optPM.add(llvm::createInstructionCombiningPass());
00263         optPM.add(llvm::createJumpThreadingPass());
00264         optPM.add(llvm::createCFGSimplificationPass());
00265         optPM.add(llvm::createScalarReplAggregatesPass());
00266         optPM.add(llvm::createInstructionCombiningPass());
00267         optPM.add(llvm::createTailCallEliminationPass());
00268 
00269         if (!g->opt.disableMaskedStoreOptimizations) {
00270             optPM.add(CreateIntrinsicsOptPass());
00271             optPM.add(CreateMaskedStoreOptPass());
00272         }
00273         optPM.add(CreateLowerMaskedStorePass());
00274         if (!g->opt.disableGatherScatterOptimizations)
00275             optPM.add(CreateGatherScatterImprovementsPass());
00276         optPM.add(CreateLowerMaskedStorePass());
00277         optPM.add(CreateLowerGatherScatterPass());
00278         optPM.add(llvm::createFunctionInliningPass());
00279         optPM.add(llvm::createConstantPropagationPass());
00280         optPM.add(CreateIntrinsicsOptPass());
00281 
00282 #if defined(LLVM_2_8)
00283         optPM.add(CreateIsCompileTimeConstantPass(true));
00284 #elif defined(LLVM_2_9)
00285         llvm::createStandardModulePasses(&optPM, 3, 
00286                                          false /* opt size */,
00287                                          true /* unit at a time */, 
00288                                          false /* unroll loops */,
00289                                          true /* simplify lib calls */,
00290                                          false /* may have exceptions */,
00291                                          llvm::createFunctionInliningPass());
00292         llvm::createStandardLTOPasses(&optPM, true /* internalize pass */,
00293                                       true /* inline once again */,
00294                                       false /* verify after each pass */);
00295         llvm::createStandardFunctionPasses(&optPM, 3);
00296 
00297         optPM.add(CreateIsCompileTimeConstantPass(true));
00298         optPM.add(CreateIntrinsicsOptPass());
00299 
00300         llvm::createStandardModulePasses(&optPM, 3, 
00301                                          false /* opt size */,
00302                                          true /* unit at a time */, 
00303                                          false /* unroll loops */,
00304                                          true /* simplify lib calls */,
00305                                          false /* may have exceptions */,
00306                                          llvm::createFunctionInliningPass());
00307 #else
00308         llvm::PassManagerBuilder builder;
00309         builder.OptLevel = 3;
00310         builder.Inliner = llvm::createFunctionInliningPass();
00311         builder.populateFunctionPassManager(funcPM);
00312         builder.populateModulePassManager(optPM);
00313         optPM.add(CreateIsCompileTimeConstantPass(true));
00314         optPM.add(CreateIntrinsicsOptPass());
00315         builder.populateLTOPassManager(optPM, true /* internalize */,
00316                                        true /* inline once again */);
00317         optPM.add(CreateIsCompileTimeConstantPass(true));
00318         optPM.add(CreateIntrinsicsOptPass());
00319         builder.populateModulePassManager(optPM);
00320 #endif
00321         optPM.add(CreateMakeInternalFuncsStaticPass());
00322         optPM.add(llvm::createGlobalDCEPass());
00323     }
00324 
00325     // Finish up by making sure we didn't mess anything up in the IR along
00326     // the way.
00327     optPM.add(llvm::createVerifierPass());
00328     
00329     for (llvm::Module::iterator fiter = module->begin(); fiter != module->end();
00330          ++fiter)
00331         funcPM.run(*fiter);
00332 
00333     optPM.run(*module);
00334 
00335     if (g->debugPrint) {
00336         printf("\n*****\nFINAL OUTPUT\n*****\n");
00337         lPrintModuleCode(module);
00338     }
00339 }

00343 ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
00344 // IntrinsicsOpt
00345 
00346 /** This is a relatively simple optimization pass that does a few small
00347     optimizations that LLVM's x86 optimizer doesn't currently handle.
00348     (Specifically, MOVMSK of a constant can be replaced with the
00349     corresponding constant value, and a BLENDVPS with either an 'all on' or
00350     'all off' blend factor can be replaced with the corredponding value of
00351     one of the two operands.
00352 
00353     @todo The better thing to do would be to submit a patch to LLVM to get
00354     these; they're presumably pretty simple patterns to match.  
00355 */
00356 class IntrinsicsOpt : public llvm::BasicBlockPass {
00357 public:
00358     IntrinsicsOpt();
00359 
00360     const char *getPassName() const { return "Intrinsics Cleanup Optimization"; }
00361     bool runOnBasicBlock(llvm::BasicBlock &BB);
00362 
00363     static char ID;
00364 
00365 private:
00366     struct MaskInstruction {
00367         MaskInstruction(llvm::Function *f) { function = f; }
00368         llvm::Function *function;
00369     };
00370     std::vector<MaskInstruction> maskInstructions;
00371 
00372     /** Structure that records everything we need to know about a blend
00373         instruction for this optimization pass.
00374      */
00375     struct BlendInstruction {
00376         BlendInstruction(llvm::Function *f, int ao, int o0, int o1, int of)
00377             : function(f), allOnMask(ao), op0(o0), op1(o1), opFactor(of) { }
00378         /** Function pointer for the blend instruction */ 
00379         llvm::Function *function;
00380         /** Mask value for an "all on" mask for this instruction */
00381         int allOnMask;
00382         /** The operand number in the llvm CallInst corresponds to the
00383             first operand to blend with. */
00384         int op0;
00385         /** The operand number in the CallInst corresponding to the second
00386             operand to blend with. */
00387         int op1;
00388         /** The operand in the call inst where the blending factor is
00389             found. */
00390         int opFactor;
00391     };
00392     std::vector<BlendInstruction> blendInstructions;
00393 
00394     bool matchesMaskInstruction(llvm::Function *function);
00395     BlendInstruction *matchingBlendInstruction(llvm::Function *function);
00396 };
00397 
00398 char IntrinsicsOpt::ID = 0;
00399 llvm::RegisterPass<IntrinsicsOpt> sse("sse-constants", "Intrinsics Cleanup Pass");
00400 
00401 
00402 IntrinsicsOpt::IntrinsicsOpt() 
00403     : BasicBlockPass(ID) {
00404 
00405     // All of the mask instructions we may encounter.  Note that even if
00406     // compiling for AVX, we may still encounter the regular 4-wide SSE
00407     // MOVMSK instruction.
00408     llvm::Function *sseMovmsk = 
00409         llvm::Intrinsic::getDeclaration(m->module, llvm::Intrinsic::x86_sse_movmsk_ps);
00410     maskInstructions.push_back(sseMovmsk);
00411     maskInstructions.push_back(m->module->getFunction("llvm.x86.avx.movmsk.ps"));
00412     maskInstructions.push_back(m->module->getFunction("llvm.x86.mic.mask16.to.int"));
00413     maskInstructions.push_back(m->module->getFunction("__movmsk"));
00414 
00415     // And all of the blend instructions
00416     blendInstructions.push_back(BlendInstruction(
00417         llvm::Intrinsic::getDeclaration(m->module, llvm::Intrinsic::x86_sse41_blendvps),
00418         0xf, 0, 1, 2));
00419     blendInstructions.push_back(BlendInstruction(
00420         m->module->getFunction("llvm.x86.avx.blendvps"), 0xff, 0, 1, 2));
00421     blendInstructions.push_back(BlendInstruction(
00422         m->module->getFunction("llvm.x86.mic.blend.ps"), 0xffff, 1, 2, 0));
00423 }
00424 
00425 
00426 /** Given an llvm::Value represinting a vector mask, see if the value is a
00427     constant.  If so, return the integer mask found by taking the high bits
00428     of the mask values in turn and concatenating them into a single integer.
00429     In other words, given the 4-wide mask: < 0xffffffff, 0, 0, 0xffffffff >, 
00430     we have 0b1001 = 9.
00431 
00432     @todo This will break if we ever do 32-wide compilation, in which case
00433     it don't be possible to distinguish between -1 for "don't know" and
00434     "known and all bits on".
00435  */
00436 static int
00437 lGetMask(llvm::Value *factor) {
00438     llvm::ConstantVector *cv = llvm::dyn_cast<llvm::ConstantVector>(factor);
00439     if (cv) {
00440         int mask = 0;
00441         llvm::SmallVector<llvm::Constant *, ISPC_MAX_NVEC> elements;
00442         cv->getVectorElements(elements);
00443 
00444         for (unsigned int i = 0; i < elements.size(); ++i) {
00445             llvm::APInt intMaskValue;
00446             // SSE has the "interesting" approach of encoding blending
00447             // masks as <n x float>.
00448             llvm::ConstantFP *cf = llvm::dyn_cast<llvm::ConstantFP>(elements[i]);
00449             if (cf) {
00450                 llvm::APFloat apf = cf->getValueAPF();
00451                 intMaskValue = apf.bitcastToAPInt();
00452             }
00453             else {
00454                 // Otherwise get it as an int
00455                 llvm::ConstantInt *ci = llvm::dyn_cast<llvm::ConstantInt>(elements[i]);
00456                 assert(ci != NULL);  // vs return -1 if NULL?
00457                 intMaskValue = ci->getValue();
00458             }
00459             // Is the high-bit set?  If so, OR in the appropriate bit in
00460             // the result mask
00461             if (intMaskValue.countLeadingOnes() > 0)
00462                 mask |= (1 << i);
00463         }
00464         return mask;
00465     }
00466     else if (llvm::isa<llvm::ConstantAggregateZero>(factor))
00467         return 0;
00468     else {
00469         // else we should be able to handle it above...
00470         assert(!llvm::isa<llvm::Constant>(factor));
00471         return -1;
00472     }
00473 }
00474 
00475 
00476 /** Given an llvm::Value, return true if we can determine that it's an
00477     undefined value.  This only makes a weak attempt at chasing this down,
00478     only detecting flat-out undef values, and bitcasts of undef values.
00479 
00480     @todo Is it worth working harder to find more of these?  It starts to
00481     get tricky, since having an undef operand doesn't necessarily mean that
00482     the result will be undefined.  (And for that matter, is there an LLVM
00483     call that will do this for us?)
00484  */
00485 static bool
00486 lIsUndef(llvm::Value *value) {
00487     if (llvm::isa<llvm::UndefValue>(value))
00488         return true;
00489 
00490     llvm::BitCastInst *bci = llvm::dyn_cast<llvm::BitCastInst>(value);
00491     if (bci)
00492         return lIsUndef(bci->getOperand(0));
00493 
00494     return false;
00495 }
00496 
00497 
00498 bool
00499 IntrinsicsOpt::runOnBasicBlock(llvm::BasicBlock &bb) {
00500     bool modifiedAny = false;
00501  restart:
00502     for (llvm::BasicBlock::iterator i = bb.begin(), e = bb.end(); i != e; ++i) {
00503         llvm::CallInst *callInst = llvm::dyn_cast<llvm::CallInst>(&*i);
00504         if (!callInst)
00505             continue;
00506 
00507         BlendInstruction *blend = matchingBlendInstruction(callInst->getCalledFunction());
00508         if (blend != NULL) {
00509             llvm::Value *v[2] = { callInst->getArgOperand(blend->op0), 
00510                                   callInst->getArgOperand(blend->op1) };
00511             llvm::Value *factor = callInst->getArgOperand(blend->opFactor);
00512 
00513             // If the values are the same, then no need to blend..
00514             if (v[0] == v[1]) {
00515                 llvm::ReplaceInstWithValue(i->getParent()->getInstList(), i, v[0]);
00516                 modifiedAny = true;
00517                 goto restart;
00518             }
00519 
00520             // If one of the two is undefined, we're allowed to replace
00521             // with the value of the other.  (In other words, the only
00522             // valid case is that the blend factor ends up having a value
00523             // that only selects from the defined one of the two operands,
00524             // otherwise the result is undefined and any value is fine,
00525             // ergo the defined one is an acceptable result.)
00526             if (lIsUndef(v[0])) {
00527                 llvm::ReplaceInstWithValue(i->getParent()->getInstList(), i, v[1]);
00528                 modifiedAny = true;
00529                 goto restart;
00530             }
00531             if (lIsUndef(v[1])) {
00532                 llvm::ReplaceInstWithValue(i->getParent()->getInstList(), i, v[0]);
00533                 modifiedAny = true;
00534                 goto restart;
00535             }
00536 
00537             int mask = lGetMask(factor);
00538             llvm::Value *value = NULL;
00539             if (mask == 0)
00540                 // Mask all off -> replace with the first blend value
00541                 value = v[0];
00542             else if (mask == blend->allOnMask)
00543                 // Mask all on -> replace with the second blend value
00544                 value = v[1];
00545 
00546             if (value != NULL) {
00547                 llvm::ReplaceInstWithValue(i->getParent()->getInstList(), i, value);
00548                 modifiedAny = true;
00549                 goto restart;
00550             }
00551         }
00552         else if (matchesMaskInstruction(callInst->getCalledFunction())) {
00553             llvm::Value *factor = callInst->getArgOperand(0);
00554             int mask = lGetMask(factor);
00555             if (mask != -1) {
00556                 // If the vector-valued mask has a known value, replace it
00557                 // with the corresponding integer mask from its elements
00558                 // high bits.
00559                 llvm::Value *value = LLVMInt32(mask);
00560                 llvm::ReplaceInstWithValue(i->getParent()->getInstList(), i, value);
00561                 modifiedAny = true;
00562                 goto restart;
00563             }
00564         }
00565     }
00566     return modifiedAny;
00567 }
00568 
00569 
00570 bool
00571 IntrinsicsOpt::matchesMaskInstruction(llvm::Function *function) {
00572     for (unsigned int i = 0; i < maskInstructions.size(); ++i)
00573         if (function == maskInstructions[i].function)
00574             return true;
00575     return false;
00576 }
00577 
00578 
00579 IntrinsicsOpt::BlendInstruction *
00580 IntrinsicsOpt::matchingBlendInstruction(llvm::Function *function) {
00581     for (unsigned int i = 0; i < blendInstructions.size(); ++i)
00582         if (function == blendInstructions[i].function)
00583             return &blendInstructions[i];
00584     return NULL;
00585 }
00586 
00587 
00588 static llvm::Pass *
00589 CreateIntrinsicsOptPass() {
00590     return new IntrinsicsOpt;
00591 }
00592 
00593 
00594 ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
00595 // GatherScatterFlattenOpt
00596 
00597 /** When the front-end emits gathers and scatters, it generates an array of
00598     vector-width pointers to represent the set of addresses to read from or
00599     write to.  However, because ispc doesn't support pointers, it turns
00600     out to be the case that scatters and gathers always end up indexing
00601     into an array with a common base pointer.  Therefore, this optimization
00602     transforms the original arrays of general pointers into a single base
00603     pointer and an array of offsets.
00604 
00605     (Implementation seems to be easier with this approach versus having the
00606     front-end try to emit base pointer + offset stuff from the start,
00607     though arguably the latter approach would be a little more elegant.)
00608 
00609     See for example the comments discussing the __pseudo_gather functions
00610     in builtins.cpp for more information about this.
00611 
00612     @todo The implementation of this is pretty messy, and it sure would be
00613     nice to not have all the complexity of built-in assumptions of the
00614     structure of how the front end will have generated code, all of the
00615     instruction dyn_casts, etc.  Can we do something simpler, e.g. an early
00616     pass to flatten out GEPs when the size is known, then do LLVM's
00617     constant folding, then flatten into an array, etc.?
00618  */
00619 class GatherScatterFlattenOpt : public llvm::BasicBlockPass {
00620 public:
00621     static char ID;
00622     GatherScatterFlattenOpt() : BasicBlockPass(ID) { }
00623 
00624     const char *getPassName() const { return "Gather/Scatter Flattening"; }
00625     bool runOnBasicBlock(llvm::BasicBlock &BB);
00626 };
00627 
00628 char GatherScatterFlattenOpt::ID = 0;
00629 
00630 llvm::RegisterPass<GatherScatterFlattenOpt> gsf("gs-flatten", "Gather/Scatter Flatten Pass");
00631 
00632 
00633 /** Given an llvm::Value known to be an unsigned integer, return its value as
00634     an int64_t.
00635 */
00636 static uint64_t
00637 lGetIntValue(llvm::Value *offset) {
00638     llvm::ConstantInt *intOffset = llvm::dyn_cast<llvm::ConstantInt>(offset);
00639     assert(intOffset && (intOffset->getBitWidth() == 32 ||
00640                          intOffset->getBitWidth() == 64));
00641     return intOffset->getZExtValue();
00642 }
00643 
00644 
00645 /** Returns the size of the given llvm::Type as an llvm::Value, if the size
00646     can be easily determined at compile type.  If it's not easy to figure
00647     out the size, this just returns NULL and we handle finding its size
00648     differently.
00649  */
00650 static bool
00651 lSizeOfIfKnown(const llvm::Type *type, uint64_t *size) {
00652     if (type == LLVMTypes::Int8Type) {
00653         *size = 1;
00654         return true;
00655     }
00656     else if (type == LLVMTypes::Int16Type) {
00657         *size = 2;
00658         return true;
00659     }
00660     else if (type == LLVMTypes::FloatType || type == LLVMTypes::Int32Type) {
00661         *size = 4;
00662         return true;
00663     }
00664     else if (type == LLVMTypes::FloatVectorType || type == LLVMTypes::Int32VectorType) {
00665         *size = g->target.vectorWidth * 4;
00666         return true;
00667     }
00668     else if (type == LLVMTypes::DoubleType || type == LLVMTypes::Int64Type) {
00669         *size = 8;
00670         return true;
00671     }
00672     else if (type == LLVMTypes::DoubleVectorType || type == LLVMTypes::Int64VectorType) {
00673         *size = g->target.vectorWidth * 8;
00674         return true;
00675     }
00676     else if (llvm::isa<const llvm::ArrayType>(type)) {
00677         const llvm::ArrayType *at = llvm::dyn_cast<const llvm::ArrayType>(type);
00678         uint64_t eltSize;
00679         if (lSizeOfIfKnown(at->getElementType(), &eltSize)) {
00680             *size = eltSize * at->getNumElements();
00681             return true;
00682         }
00683         else
00684             return false;
00685     }
00686     return false;
00687 }
00688 
00689 
00690 /** This function returns an llvm::Value giving the size of the given type.
00691     If any instructions need to be generated to compute the size, they are
00692     inserted before insertBefore.
00693  */
00694 static llvm::Value *
00695 lSizeOf(const llvm::Type *type, llvm::Instruction *insertBefore) {
00696     // First try the easy case and see if we can get it as a simple
00697     // constant..
00698     uint64_t size;
00699     if (lSizeOfIfKnown(type, &size))
00700         return LLVMInt64(size);
00701 
00702     // Otherwise use the trick of doing a GEP with a NULL pointer to get
00703     // the pointer to the second element of an array of items of this type.
00704     // Then convert that pointer to an int and we've got the offset to the
00705     // second element in the array, a.k.a. the size of the type.
00706     const llvm::Type *ptrType = llvm::PointerType::get(type, 0);
00707     llvm::Value *nullPtr = llvm::Constant::getNullValue(ptrType);
00708     llvm::Value *index[1] = { LLVMInt32(1) };
00709     llvm::Value *poffset = llvm::GetElementPtrInst::Create(nullPtr, &index[0], &index[1],
00710                                                            "offset_ptr", insertBefore);
00711     lCopyMetadata(poffset, insertBefore);
00712     llvm::Instruction *inst = new llvm::PtrToIntInst(poffset, LLVMTypes::Int64Type, 
00713                                                      "offset_int", insertBefore);
00714     lCopyMetadata(inst, insertBefore);
00715     return inst;
00716 }
00717 
00718 
00719 /** This function returns a value that gives the offset in bytes from the
00720     start of the given structure type to the given struct member.  The
00721     instructions that compute this value are inserted before insertBefore.
00722  */
00723 static llvm::Value *
00724 lStructOffset(const llvm::Type *type, uint64_t member, 
00725               llvm::Instruction *insertBefore) {
00726     // Do a similar trick to the one done in lSizeOf above; compute the
00727     // pointer to the member starting from a NULL base pointer and then
00728     // cast that 'pointer' to an int...
00729     assert(llvm::isa<const llvm::StructType>(type));
00730     const llvm::Type *ptrType = llvm::PointerType::get(type, 0);
00731     llvm::Value *nullPtr = llvm::Constant::getNullValue(ptrType);
00732     llvm::Value *index[2] = { LLVMInt32(0), LLVMInt32((int32_t)member) };
00733     llvm::Value *poffset = llvm::GetElementPtrInst::Create(nullPtr, &index[0], &index[2],
00734                                                            "member_ptr", insertBefore);
00735     lCopyMetadata(poffset, insertBefore);
00736     llvm::Instruction *inst = new llvm::PtrToIntInst(poffset, LLVMTypes::Int64Type, 
00737                                                      "member_int", insertBefore);
00738     lCopyMetadata(inst, insertBefore);
00739     return inst;
00740 }
00741 
00742 
00743 static llvm::Value *
00744 lGetTypeSize(const llvm::Type *type, llvm::Instruction *insertBefore) {
00745     const llvm::ArrayType *arrayType =  llvm::dyn_cast<const llvm::ArrayType>(type);
00746     if (arrayType != NULL)
00747         type = arrayType->getElementType();
00748 
00749     llvm::Value *scale = lSizeOf(type, insertBefore);
00750     llvm::Instruction *inst = new llvm::TruncInst(scale, LLVMTypes::Int32Type, "sizeof32", 
00751                                                   insertBefore);
00752     lCopyMetadata(inst, insertBefore);
00753     return inst;
00754 }
00755 
00756 
00757 static llvm::Value *
00758 lGetOffsetForLane(int lane, llvm::Value *value, llvm::Value **offset, 
00759                   const llvm::Type **scaleType, bool *leafIsVarying,
00760                   llvm::Instruction *insertBefore) {
00761     if (!llvm::isa<llvm::GetElementPtrInst>(value)) {
00762         assert(llvm::isa<llvm::BitCastInst>(value));
00763         value = llvm::dyn_cast<llvm::BitCastInst>(value)->getOperand(0);
00764 
00765         llvm::ExtractValueInst *ev = llvm::dyn_cast<llvm::ExtractValueInst>(value);
00766         assert(ev->hasIndices() && ev->getNumIndices() == 1);
00767         assert(int(*(ev->idx_begin())) == lane);
00768 
00769         llvm::InsertValueInst *iv = llvm::dyn_cast<llvm::InsertValueInst>(ev->getOperand(0));
00770         assert(iv->hasIndices() && iv->getNumIndices() == 1);
00771         while (int(*(iv->idx_begin())) != lane) {
00772             iv = llvm::dyn_cast<llvm::InsertValueInst>(iv->getOperand(0));
00773             assert(iv && iv->hasIndices() && iv->getNumIndices() == 1);
00774         }
00775     
00776         value = iv->getOperand(1);
00777     }
00778 
00779     if (leafIsVarying != NULL) {
00780         const llvm::Type *pt = value->getType();
00781         const llvm::PointerType *ptrType = llvm::dyn_cast<const llvm::PointerType>(pt);
00782         assert(ptrType);
00783         const llvm::Type *eltType = ptrType->getElementType();
00784         *leafIsVarying = llvm::isa<const llvm::VectorType>(eltType);
00785     }
00786 
00787     llvm::GetElementPtrInst *gep = llvm::dyn_cast<llvm::GetElementPtrInst>(value);
00788     assert(gep);
00789 
00790     assert(lGetIntValue(gep->getOperand(1)) == 0);
00791     const llvm::PointerType *targetPtrType = 
00792         llvm::dyn_cast<const llvm::PointerType>(gep->getOperand(0)->getType());
00793     assert(targetPtrType);
00794     const llvm::Type *targetType = targetPtrType->getElementType();
00795 
00796     if (llvm::isa<const llvm::StructType>(targetType)) {
00797         *offset = lStructOffset(targetType, lGetIntValue(gep->getOperand(2)),
00798                                 insertBefore);
00799         *offset = new llvm::TruncInst(*offset, LLVMTypes::Int32Type, "member32", 
00800                                       insertBefore);
00801         lCopyMetadata(*offset, insertBefore);
00802         *scaleType = LLVMTypes::Int8Type; // aka char aka sizeof(1)
00803     }
00804     else {
00805         *offset = gep->getOperand(2);
00806         assert(*scaleType == NULL || *scaleType == targetType);
00807         *scaleType = targetType;
00808     }
00809 
00810     llvm::ExtractValueInst *ee = 
00811         llvm::dyn_cast<llvm::ExtractValueInst>(gep->getOperand(0));
00812     if (ee == NULL) {
00813         // found the base pointer, here it is...
00814         return gep->getOperand(0);
00815     }
00816     else {
00817         assert(ee->hasIndices() && ee->getNumIndices() == 1 &&
00818                int(*(ee->idx_begin())) == lane);
00819         llvm::InsertValueInst *iv =
00820             llvm::dyn_cast<llvm::InsertValueInst>(ee->getOperand(0));
00821         assert(iv != NULL);
00822         // do this chain of inserts for the next dimension...
00823         return iv;
00824     }
00825 }
00826 
00827 
00828 /** We have an LLVM array of pointer values, where each pointer has been
00829     computed with a GEP from some common base pointer value.  This function
00830     deconstructs the LLVM array, storing the offset from the base pointer
00831     as an llvm::Value for the i'th element into the i'th element of the
00832     offsets[] array passed in to the function.  It returns a scale factor
00833     for the offsets via *scaleType, and sets *leafIsVarying to true if the
00834     leaf data type being indexed into is a 'varying' ispc type.  The
00835     return value is either the base pointer or the an array of pointers for
00836     the next dimension of indexing (that we'll in turn deconstruct with
00837     this function).
00838 
00839     @todo All of the additional indexing magic for varying stuff should
00840     happen in the front end.
00841  */
00842 static llvm::Value *
00843 lTraverseInsertChain(llvm::Value *ptrs, llvm::Value *offsets[ISPC_MAX_NVEC],
00844                      const llvm::Type **scaleType, bool *leafIsVarying,
00845                      llvm::Instruction *insertBefore) {
00846     // This depends on the front-end constructing the arrays of pointers
00847     // via InsertValue instructions.  (Which it does do in
00848     // FunctionEmitContext::GetElementPtrInst()).
00849     llvm::InsertValueInst *ivInst = llvm::dyn_cast<llvm::InsertValueInst>(ptrs);
00850     assert(ivInst != NULL);
00851 
00852     // We have a chain of insert value instructions where each instruction
00853     // sets one of the elements of the array and where the input array is
00854     // either the base pointer or another insert value instruction.  Here
00855     // we talk through all of the insert value instructions until we hit
00856     // the end.
00857     llvm::Value *nextChain = NULL;
00858     while (ivInst != NULL) {
00859         // Figure out which array index this current instruction is setting
00860         // the value of.
00861         assert(ivInst->hasIndices() && ivInst->getNumIndices() == 1);
00862         int elementIndex = *(ivInst->idx_begin());
00863         assert(elementIndex >= 0 && elementIndex < g->target.vectorWidth);
00864         // We shouldn't have already seen something setting the value for
00865         // this index.
00866         assert(offsets[elementIndex] == NULL);
00867 
00868         // Set offsets[elementIndex] here.  This returns the value from
00869         // which the GEP operation was done; this should either be the base
00870         // pointer or an insert value chain for another dimension of the
00871         // array being indexed into.
00872         llvm::Value *myNext = lGetOffsetForLane(elementIndex, ivInst->getOperand(1), 
00873                                                 &offsets[elementIndex], scaleType,
00874                                                 leafIsVarying, insertBefore);
00875         if (nextChain == NULL)
00876             nextChain = myNext;
00877         else
00878             // All of these insert value instructions should have the same
00879             // base value
00880             assert(nextChain == myNext);
00881 
00882         // Do we have another element of the array to process?
00883         llvm::Value *nextInsert = ivInst->getOperand(0);
00884         ivInst = llvm::dyn_cast<llvm::InsertValueInst>(nextInsert);
00885         if (!ivInst)
00886             assert(llvm::isa<llvm::UndefValue>(nextInsert));
00887     }
00888     return nextChain;
00889 }
00890 
00891 
00892 /** Given a scalar value, return a vector of width g->target.vectorWidth
00893     that has the scalar replicated across each of its elements.
00894 
00895     @todo Using shufflevector to do this seems more idiomatic (and would be
00896     just a single instruction).  Switch to that?
00897  */
00898 static llvm::Value *
00899 lSmearScalar(llvm::Value *scalar, llvm::Instruction *insertBefore) {
00900     const llvm::Type *vectorType = llvm::VectorType::get(scalar->getType(), 
00901                                                          g->target.vectorWidth);
00902     llvm::Value *result = llvm::UndefValue::get(vectorType);
00903     for (int i = 0; i < g->target.vectorWidth; ++i) {
00904         result = llvm::InsertElementInst::Create(result, scalar, LLVMInt32(i),
00905                                                  "smearinsert", insertBefore);
00906         lCopyMetadata(result, insertBefore);
00907     }
00908     return result;
00909 }
00910 
00911 
00912 static llvm::Value *
00913 lGetPtrAndOffsets(llvm::Value *ptrs, llvm::Value **basePtr, 
00914                   llvm::Instruction *insertBefore, int eltSize) {
00915     llvm::Value *offset = LLVMInt32Vector(0);
00916     bool firstLoop = true, leafIsVarying;
00917 
00918     while (ptrs != NULL) {
00919         llvm::Value *offsets[ISPC_MAX_NVEC];
00920         for (int i = 0; i < g->target.vectorWidth; ++i)
00921             offsets[i] = NULL;
00922         const llvm::Type *scaleType = NULL;
00923 
00924         llvm::Value *nextChain = 
00925             lTraverseInsertChain(ptrs, offsets, &scaleType,
00926                                  firstLoop ? &leafIsVarying : NULL, insertBefore);
00927 
00928         for (int i = 0; i < g->target.vectorWidth; ++i)
00929             assert(offsets[i] != NULL);
00930         llvm::Value *delta = llvm::UndefValue::get(LLVMTypes::Int32VectorType);
00931         for (int i = 0; i < g->target.vectorWidth; ++i) {
00932             delta = llvm::InsertElementInst::Create(delta, offsets[i],
00933                                                     LLVMInt32(i), "dim",
00934                                                     insertBefore);
00935             lCopyMetadata(delta, insertBefore);
00936         }
00937 
00938         llvm::Value *size = lGetTypeSize(scaleType, insertBefore);
00939 
00940         llvm::Value *scale = lSmearScalar(size, insertBefore);
00941         delta = llvm::BinaryOperator::Create(llvm::Instruction::Mul, delta, 
00942                                              scale, "delta_scale", insertBefore);
00943         lCopyMetadata(delta, insertBefore);
00944         offset = llvm::BinaryOperator::Create(llvm::Instruction::Add, offset, 
00945                                               delta, "offset_delta", 
00946                                               insertBefore);
00947         lCopyMetadata(offset, insertBefore);
00948 
00949         if (llvm::dyn_cast<llvm::InsertValueInst>(nextChain))
00950             ptrs = nextChain;
00951         else {
00952             // else we don't have a unique starting pointer....
00953             assert(*basePtr == NULL || *basePtr == nextChain);
00954             *basePtr = nextChain;
00955             break;
00956         }
00957         firstLoop = false;
00958     }
00959 
00960     // handle varying stuff...
00961     if (leafIsVarying) {
00962         llvm::Value *deltaVector = llvm::UndefValue::get(LLVMTypes::Int32VectorType);
00963         for (int i = 0; i < g->target.vectorWidth; ++i) {
00964             deltaVector = 
00965                 llvm::InsertElementInst::Create(deltaVector, LLVMInt32(eltSize*i),
00966                                                 LLVMInt32(i), "delta", insertBefore);
00967             lCopyMetadata(deltaVector, insertBefore);
00968         }
00969         offset = llvm::BinaryOperator::Create(llvm::Instruction::Add, offset, 
00970                                               deltaVector, "offset_varying_delta", 
00971                                               insertBefore);
00972         lCopyMetadata(offset, insertBefore);
00973     }
00974 
00975     return offset;
00976 }
00977 
00978 
00979 bool
00980 GatherScatterFlattenOpt::runOnBasicBlock(llvm::BasicBlock &bb) {
00981     llvm::Function *gather32Func = m->module->getFunction("__pseudo_gather_32");
00982     llvm::Function *gather64Func = m->module->getFunction("__pseudo_gather_64");
00983     llvm::Function *scatter32Func = m->module->getFunction("__pseudo_scatter_32");
00984     llvm::Function *scatter64Func = m->module->getFunction("__pseudo_scatter_64");
00985     assert(gather32Func && gather64Func && scatter32Func && scatter64Func);
00986 
00987     bool modifiedAny = false;
00988  restart:
00989     // Iterate through all of the instructions in the basic block.
00990     for (llvm::BasicBlock::iterator i = bb.begin(), e = bb.end(); i != e; ++i) {
00991         llvm::CallInst *callInst = llvm::dyn_cast<llvm::CallInst>(&*i);
00992         // If we don't have a call to one of the
00993         // __pseudo_{gather,scatter}_* functions, then just go on to the
00994         // next instruction.
00995         if (!callInst ||
00996             (callInst->getCalledFunction() != gather32Func &&
00997              callInst->getCalledFunction() != gather64Func &&
00998              callInst->getCalledFunction() != scatter32Func &&
00999              callInst->getCalledFunction() != scatter64Func))
01000             continue;
01001 
01002         bool isGather = (callInst->getCalledFunction() == gather32Func ||
01003                          callInst->getCalledFunction() == gather64Func);
01004         bool is32 = (callInst->getCalledFunction() == gather32Func ||
01005                      callInst->getCalledFunction() == scatter32Func);
01006 
01007         // Transform the array of pointers to a single base pointer and an
01008         // array of int32 offsets.  (All the hard work is done by
01009         // lGetPtrAndOffsets).
01010         llvm::Value *ptrs = callInst->getArgOperand(0);
01011         llvm::Value *basePtr = NULL;
01012         llvm::Value *offsetVector = lGetPtrAndOffsets(ptrs, &basePtr, callInst, 
01013                                                       is32 ? 4 : 8);
01014         // Cast the base pointer to a void *, since that's what the
01015         // __pseudo_*_base_offsets_* functions want.
01016         basePtr = new llvm::BitCastInst(basePtr, LLVMTypes::VoidPointerType, "base2void", 
01017                                         callInst);
01018         lCopyMetadata(basePtr, callInst);
01019 
01020         if (isGather) {
01021             llvm::Value *mask = callInst->getArgOperand(1);
01022             llvm::Function *gFunc = 
01023                 m->module->getFunction(is32 ? "__pseudo_gather_base_offsets_32" :
01024                                               "__pseudo_gather_base_offsets_64");
01025             assert(gFunc != NULL);
01026 
01027             // Generate a new function call to the next pseudo gather
01028             // base+offsets instruction.  Note that we're passing a NULL
01029             // llvm::BasicBlock to llvm::CallInst::Create; this means that
01030             // the instruction isn't inserted into a basic block and that
01031             // way we can then call ReplaceInstWithInst().
01032             llvm::Value *newArgs[3] = { basePtr, offsetVector, mask };
01033             llvm::Instruction *newCall = 
01034                 llvm::CallInst::Create(gFunc, &newArgs[0], &newArgs[3], "newgather");
01035             lCopyMetadata(newCall, callInst);
01036             llvm::ReplaceInstWithInst(callInst, newCall);
01037         }
01038         else {
01039             llvm::Value *mask = callInst->getArgOperand(2);
01040             llvm::Value *rvalue = callInst->getArgOperand(1);
01041             llvm::Function *gFunc = 
01042                 m->module->getFunction(is32 ? "__pseudo_scatter_base_offsets_32" :
01043                                               "__pseudo_scatter_base_offsets_64");
01044             assert(gFunc);
01045 
01046             // Generate a new function call to the next pseudo scatter
01047             // base+offsets instruction.  See above for why passing NULL
01048             // for the basic block is intended.
01049             llvm::Value *newArgs[4] = { basePtr, offsetVector, rvalue, mask };
01050             llvm::Instruction *newCall = 
01051                 llvm::CallInst::Create(gFunc, &newArgs[0], &newArgs[4]);
01052             lCopyMetadata(newCall, callInst);
01053             llvm::ReplaceInstWithInst(callInst, newCall);
01054         }
01055         modifiedAny = true;
01056         goto restart;
01057     }
01058     return modifiedAny;
01059 }
01060 
01061 
01062 static llvm::Pass *
01063 CreateGatherScatterFlattenPass() {
01064     return new GatherScatterFlattenOpt;
01065 }
01066 
01067 
01068 ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
01069 // MaskedStoreOptPass
01070 
01071 /** Masked stores are generally more complex than regular stores; for
01072     example, they require multiple instructions to simulate under SSE.
01073     This optimization detects cases where masked stores can be replaced
01074     with regular stores or removed entirely, for the cases of an 'all on'
01075     mask and an 'all off' mask, respectively.
01076  */
01077 class MaskedStoreOptPass : public llvm::BasicBlockPass {
01078 public:
01079     static char ID;
01080     MaskedStoreOptPass() : BasicBlockPass(ID) { }
01081 
01082     const char *getPassName() const { return "Masked Store Scalarize"; }
01083     bool runOnBasicBlock(llvm::BasicBlock &BB);
01084 };
01085 
01086 
01087 char MaskedStoreOptPass::ID = 0;
01088 
01089 llvm::RegisterPass<MaskedStoreOptPass> mss("masked-store-scalarize",
01090                                            "Masked Store Scalarize Pass");
01091 
01092 bool
01093 MaskedStoreOptPass::runOnBasicBlock(llvm::BasicBlock &bb) {
01094     llvm::Function *pms32Func = m->module->getFunction("__pseudo_masked_store_32");
01095     llvm::Function *pms64Func = m->module->getFunction("__pseudo_masked_store_64");
01096     llvm::Function *msb32Func = m->module->getFunction("__masked_store_blend_32");
01097     llvm::Function *msb64Func = m->module->getFunction("__masked_store_blend_64");
01098     llvm::Function *ms32Func = m->module->getFunction("__masked_store_32");
01099     llvm::Function *ms64Func = m->module->getFunction("__masked_store_64");
01100 
01101     bool modifiedAny = false;
01102  restart:
01103     // Iterate over all of the instructions to look for one of the various
01104     // masked store functions
01105     for (llvm::BasicBlock::iterator i = bb.begin(), e = bb.end(); i != e; ++i) {
01106         llvm::CallInst *callInst = llvm::dyn_cast<llvm::CallInst>(&*i);
01107         if (!callInst)
01108             continue;
01109 
01110         llvm::Function *called = callInst->getCalledFunction();
01111         if (called != pms32Func && called != pms64Func &&
01112             called != msb32Func && called != msb64Func &&
01113             called != ms32Func  && called != ms64Func)
01114             continue;
01115 
01116         // Got one; grab the operands
01117         llvm::Value *lvalue = callInst->getArgOperand(0);
01118         llvm::Value *rvalue  = callInst->getArgOperand(1);
01119         llvm::Value *mask = callInst->getArgOperand(2);
01120 
01121         int allOnMask = (1 << g->target.vectorWidth) - 1;
01122 
01123         int maskAsInt = lGetMask(mask);
01124         if (maskAsInt == 0) {
01125             // Zero mask - no-op, so remove the store completely.  (This
01126             // may in turn lead to being able to optimize out instructions
01127             // that compute the rvalue...)
01128             callInst->eraseFromParent();
01129             modifiedAny = true;
01130             goto restart;
01131         }
01132         else if (maskAsInt == allOnMask) {
01133             // The mask is all on, so turn this into a regular store
01134             const llvm::Type *rvalueType = rvalue->getType();
01135             const llvm::Type *ptrType = llvm::PointerType::get(rvalueType, 0);
01136             // Need to update this when int8/int16 are added
01137             int align = (called == pms32Func || called == pms64Func ||
01138                          called == msb32Func) ? 4 : 8;
01139 
01140             lvalue = new llvm::BitCastInst(lvalue, ptrType, "lvalue_to_ptr_type", callInst);
01141             lCopyMetadata(lvalue, callInst);
01142             llvm::Instruction *store = 
01143                 new llvm::StoreInst(rvalue, lvalue, false /* not volatile */,
01144                                     align);
01145             lCopyMetadata(store, callInst);
01146             llvm::ReplaceInstWithInst(callInst, store);
01147 
01148             modifiedAny = true;
01149             goto restart;
01150         }
01151     }
01152     return modifiedAny;
01153 }
01154 
01155 
01156 static llvm::Pass *
01157 CreateMaskedStoreOptPass() {
01158     return new MaskedStoreOptPass;
01159 }
01160 
01161 
01162 ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
01163 // LowerMaskedStorePass
01164 
01165 /** When the front-end needs to do a masked store, it emits a
01166     __pseudo_masked_store_{32,64} call as a placeholder.  This pass lowers
01167     these calls to either __masked_store_{32,64} or
01168     __masked_store_blend_{32,64} calls.
01169   */
01170 class LowerMaskedStorePass : public llvm::BasicBlockPass {
01171 public:
01172     static char ID;
01173     LowerMaskedStorePass() : BasicBlockPass(ID) { }
01174 
01175     const char *getPassName() const { return "Lower Masked Stores"; }
01176     bool runOnBasicBlock(llvm::BasicBlock &BB);
01177 };
01178 
01179 
01180 char LowerMaskedStorePass::ID = 0;
01181 
01182 llvm::RegisterPass<LowerMaskedStorePass> lms("masked-store-lower",
01183                                              "Lower Masked Store Pass");
01184 
01185 
01186 /** This routine attempts to determine if the given pointer in lvalue is
01187     pointing to stack-allocated memory.  It's conservative in that it
01188     should never return true for non-stack allocated memory, but may return
01189     false for memory that actually is stack allocated.  The basic strategy
01190     is to traverse through the operands and see if the pointer originally
01191     comes from an AllocaInst.
01192  */
01193 static bool
01194 lIsStackVariablePointer(llvm::Value *lvalue) {
01195     llvm::BitCastInst *bc = llvm::dyn_cast<llvm::BitCastInst>(lvalue);
01196     if (bc)
01197         return lIsStackVariablePointer(bc->getOperand(0));
01198     else {
01199         llvm::AllocaInst *ai = llvm::dyn_cast<llvm::AllocaInst>(lvalue);
01200         if (ai)
01201             return true;
01202         else {
01203             llvm::GetElementPtrInst *gep = llvm::dyn_cast<llvm::GetElementPtrInst>(lvalue);
01204             if (gep)
01205                 return lIsStackVariablePointer(gep->getOperand(0));
01206             else
01207                 return false;
01208         }
01209     }
01210 }
01211 
01212 
01213 /** Utilty routine to figure out which masked store function to use.  The
01214     blend parameter indicates if we want the blending version, is32
01215     indicates if the element size is 32 bits.
01216  */
01217 static const char *
01218 lMaskedStoreName(bool blend, bool is32) {
01219     if (blend) {
01220         if (is32)
01221             return "__masked_store_blend_32";
01222         else
01223             return "__masked_store_blend_64";
01224     }
01225     else {
01226         if (is32)
01227             return "__masked_store_32";
01228         else
01229             return "__masked_store_64";
01230     }
01231 }
01232 
01233 
01234 bool
01235 LowerMaskedStorePass::runOnBasicBlock(llvm::BasicBlock &bb) {
01236     llvm::Function *maskedStore32Func = m->module->getFunction("__pseudo_masked_store_32");
01237     llvm::Function *maskedStore64Func = m->module->getFunction("__pseudo_masked_store_64");
01238     assert(maskedStore32Func && maskedStore64Func);
01239 
01240     bool modifiedAny = false;
01241  restart:
01242     for (llvm::BasicBlock::iterator i = bb.begin(), e = bb.end(); i != e; ++i) {
01243         // Iterate through all of the instructions and look for
01244         // __pseudo_masked_store_* calls.
01245         llvm::CallInst *callInst = llvm::dyn_cast<llvm::CallInst>(&*i);
01246         if (!callInst ||
01247             (callInst->getCalledFunction() != maskedStore32Func &&
01248              callInst->getCalledFunction() != maskedStore64Func))
01249             continue;
01250 
01251         bool is32 = (callInst->getCalledFunction() == maskedStore32Func);
01252         llvm::Value *lvalue = callInst->getArgOperand(0);
01253         llvm::Value *rvalue  = callInst->getArgOperand(1);
01254         llvm::Value *mask = callInst->getArgOperand(2);
01255 
01256         // On SSE, we need to choose between doing the load + blend + store
01257         // trick, or serializing the masked store.  On targets with a
01258         // native masked store instruction, the implementations of
01259         // __masked_store_blend_* should be the same as __masked_store_*,
01260         // so this doesn't matter.  On SSE, blending is generally more
01261         // efficient and is always safe to do on stack-allocated values.(?)
01262         bool doBlend = lIsStackVariablePointer(lvalue);
01263         if (g->target.isa == Target::SSE4 || g->target.isa == Target::SSE2)
01264             doBlend |= !g->opt.disableBlendedMaskedStores;
01265 
01266         // Generate the call to the appropriate masked store function and
01267         // replace the __pseudo_* one with it.
01268         llvm::Function *fms = m->module->getFunction(lMaskedStoreName(doBlend, is32));
01269         assert(fms);
01270         llvm::Value *args[3] = { lvalue, rvalue, mask };
01271         llvm::Instruction *inst = llvm::CallInst::Create(fms, &args[0], &args[3], "", 
01272                                                          callInst);
01273         lCopyMetadata(inst, callInst);
01274 
01275         callInst->eraseFromParent();
01276         modifiedAny = true;
01277         goto restart;
01278     }
01279     return modifiedAny;
01280 }
01281 
01282 
01283 static llvm::Pass *
01284 CreateLowerMaskedStorePass() {
01285     return new LowerMaskedStorePass;
01286 }
01287 
01288 ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
01289 // GSImprovementsPass
01290 
01291 /** After earlier optimization passes have run, we are sometimes able to
01292     determine that gathers/scatters are actually accessing memory in a more
01293     regular fashion and then change the operation to something simpler and
01294     more efficient.  For example, if all of the lanes in a gather are
01295     reading from the same location, we can instead do a scalar load and
01296     broadcast.  This pass examines gathers and scatters and tries to
01297     simplify them if at all possible.
01298 
01299     @todo Currently, this only looks for all program instances going to the
01300     same location and all going to a linear sequence of locations in
01301     memory.  There are a number of other cases that might make sense to
01302     look for, including things that could be handled with a vector load +
01303     shuffle or things that could be handled with hybrids of e.g. 2 4-wide
01304     vector loads with AVX, etc.
01305  */
01306 class GSImprovementsPass : public llvm::BasicBlockPass {
01307 public:
01308     static char ID;
01309     GSImprovementsPass() : BasicBlockPass(ID) { }
01310 
01311     const char *getPassName() const { return "Gather/Scatter Improvements"; }
01312     bool runOnBasicBlock(llvm::BasicBlock &BB);
01313 };
01314 
01315 
01316 char GSImprovementsPass::ID = 0;
01317 
01318 llvm::RegisterPass<GSImprovementsPass> gsi("gs-improvements",
01319                                            "Gather/Scatter Improvements Pass");
01320 
01321 
01322 #if 0
01323 // Debugging routine: dump the values of all of the elmenets in a
01324 // flattened-out vector
01325 static void lPrintVector(const char *info, llvm::Value *elements[ISPC_MAX_NVEC]) {
01326     fprintf(stderr, "--- %s ---\n", info);
01327     for (int i = 0; i < g->target.vectorWidth; ++i) {
01328         fprintf(stderr, "%d: ", i);
01329         elements[i]->dump();
01330     }
01331     fprintf(stderr, "-----\n");
01332 }
01333 #endif
01334 
01335 
01336 /** Given an LLVM vector in vec, return a 'scalarized' version of the
01337     vector in the provided offsets[] array.  For example, if the vector
01338     value passed in is:  
01339 
01340     add <4 x i32> %a_smear, <4 x i32> <4, 8, 12, 16>,
01341 
01342     and if %a_smear was computed by replicating a scalar value i32 %a
01343     across all of the elements of %a_smear, then the values returned will
01344     be:
01345 
01346     offsets[0] = add i32 %a, i32 4
01347     offsets[1] = add i32 %a, i32 8
01348     offsets[2] = add i32 %a, i32 12
01349     offsets[3] = add i32 %a, i32 16
01350     
01351     This function isn't fully general, but it seems to be able to handle
01352     all of the patterns that currently arise in practice.  If it can't
01353     scalarize a vector value, then it just returns false and the calling
01354     code proceeds as best it can without this information.
01355 
01356     @param vec               Vector to be scalarized
01357     @param scalarizedVector  Array in which to store the individual vector 
01358                              elements
01359     @returns                 True if the vector was successfully scalarized and
01360                              the values in offsets[] are valid; false otherwise
01361  */
01362 static bool
01363 lScalarizeVector(llvm::Value *vec, llvm::Value *scalarizedVector[ISPC_MAX_NVEC]) {
01364     // First initialize the values of scalarizedVector[] to NULL.
01365     for (int i = 0; i < g->target.vectorWidth; ++i)
01366         scalarizedVector[i] = NULL;
01367 
01368     // ConstantVectors are easy; just pull out the individual constant
01369     // element values
01370     llvm::ConstantVector *cv = llvm::dyn_cast<llvm::ConstantVector>(vec);
01371     if (cv != NULL) {
01372         for (int i = 0; i < g->target.vectorWidth; ++i)
01373             scalarizedVector[i] = cv->getOperand(i);
01374         return true;
01375     }
01376 
01377     // It's also easy if it's just a vector of all zeros
01378     llvm::ConstantAggregateZero *caz = llvm::dyn_cast<llvm::ConstantAggregateZero>(vec);
01379     if (caz) {
01380         for (int i = 0; i < g->target.vectorWidth; ++i)
01381             scalarizedVector[i] = LLVMInt32(0);
01382         return true;
01383     }
01384 
01385     llvm::BinaryOperator *bo = llvm::dyn_cast<llvm::BinaryOperator>(vec);
01386     if (bo) {
01387         // BinaryOperators are handled by attempting to scalarize both of
01388         // the operands.  If we're successful at this, then the vector of
01389         // scalar values we return from here are synthesized with scalar
01390         // versions of the original vector binary operator
01391         llvm::Instruction::BinaryOps opcode = bo->getOpcode();
01392         llvm::Value *v0[ISPC_MAX_NVEC], *v1[ISPC_MAX_NVEC];
01393 
01394         if (!lScalarizeVector(bo->getOperand(0), v0) || 
01395             !lScalarizeVector(bo->getOperand(1), v1))
01396             return false;
01397 
01398         for (int i = 0; i < g->target.vectorWidth; ++i) {
01399             scalarizedVector[i] = 
01400                 llvm::BinaryOperator::Create(opcode, v0[i], v1[i], "flat_bop", bo);
01401             lCopyMetadata(scalarizedVector[i], bo);
01402         }
01403 
01404         return true;
01405     }
01406 
01407     llvm::InsertElementInst *ie = llvm::dyn_cast<llvm::InsertElementInst>(vec);
01408     if (ie != NULL) {
01409         // If we have an InsertElement instruction, we generally have a
01410         // chain along the lines of:
01411         //
01412         // %v0 = insertelement undef, value_0, i32 index_0
01413         // %v1 = insertelement %v1,   value_1, i32 index_1
01414         // ...
01415         // %vn = insertelement %vn-1, value_n-1, i32 index_n-1
01416         //
01417         // We start here witn %vn and work backwards through the chain of
01418         // insertelement instructions until we get to the undef value that
01419         // started it all.  At each instruction, we set the appropriate
01420         // vaue in scalarizedVector[] based on the value being inserted.
01421         while (ie != NULL) {
01422             uint64_t iOffset = lGetIntValue(ie->getOperand(2));
01423             assert((int)iOffset < g->target.vectorWidth);
01424             assert(scalarizedVector[iOffset] == NULL);
01425 
01426             scalarizedVector[iOffset] = ie->getOperand(1);
01427 
01428             llvm::Value *insertBase = ie->getOperand(0);
01429             ie = llvm::dyn_cast<llvm::InsertElementInst>(insertBase);
01430             if (!ie)
01431                 assert(llvm::isa<llvm::UndefValue>(insertBase));
01432         }
01433         return true;
01434     }
01435 
01436     llvm::CastInst *ci = llvm::dyn_cast<llvm::CastInst>(vec);
01437     if (ci) {
01438         // Casts are similar to BinaryOperators in that we attempt to
01439         // scalarize the vector being cast and if successful, we apply
01440         // equivalent scalar cast operators to each of the values in the
01441         // scalarized vector.
01442         llvm::Instruction::CastOps op = ci->getOpcode();
01443 
01444         llvm::Value *scalarizedTarget[ISPC_MAX_NVEC];
01445         if (!lScalarizeVector(ci->getOperand(0), scalarizedTarget))
01446             return false;
01447 
01448         const llvm::Type *destType = ci->getDestTy();
01449         const llvm::VectorType *vectorDestType =
01450             llvm::dyn_cast<const llvm::VectorType>(destType);
01451         assert(vectorDestType != NULL);
01452         const llvm::Type *elementType = vectorDestType->getElementType();
01453 
01454         for (int i = 0; i < g->target.vectorWidth; ++i) {
01455             scalarizedVector[i] = 
01456                 llvm::CastInst::Create(op, scalarizedTarget[i], elementType,
01457                                        "cast", ci);
01458             lCopyMetadata(scalarizedVector[i], ci);
01459         }
01460         return true;
01461     }
01462 
01463     llvm::ShuffleVectorInst *svi = llvm::dyn_cast<llvm::ShuffleVectorInst>(vec);
01464     if (svi) {
01465         // Note that the code for shufflevector instructions is untested.
01466         // (We haven't yet had a case where it needs to run).  Therefore,
01467         // an assert at the bottom of this routien will hit the first time
01468         // it runs as a reminder that this needs to be tested further.
01469 
01470         const llvm::VectorType *svInstType = 
01471             llvm::dyn_cast<const llvm::VectorType>(svi->getType());
01472         assert(svInstType != NULL);
01473         assert((int)svInstType->getNumElements() == g->target.vectorWidth);
01474 
01475         // Scalarize the two vectors being shuffled.  First figure out how
01476         // big they are.
01477         const llvm::Type *type0 = svi->getOperand(0)->getType();
01478         const llvm::Type *type1 = svi->getOperand(1)->getType();
01479         const llvm::VectorType *vectorType0 = 
01480             llvm::dyn_cast<const llvm::VectorType>(type0);
01481         const llvm::VectorType *vectorType1 = 
01482             llvm::dyn_cast<const llvm::VectorType>(type1);
01483         assert(vectorType0 != NULL && vectorType1 != NULL);
01484 
01485         int n0 = vectorType0->getNumElements();
01486         int n1 = vectorType1->getNumElements();
01487 
01488         // FIXME: It's actually totally legitimate for these two to have
01489         // different sizes; the final result just needs to have the native
01490         // vector width.  To handle this, not only do we need to
01491         // potentially dynamically allocate space for the arrays passed
01492         // into lScalarizeVector, but we need to change the rest of its
01493         // implementation to not key off g->target.vectorWidth everywhere
01494         // to get the sizes of the arrays to iterate over, etc.
01495         assert(n0 == g->target.vectorWidth && n1 == g->target.vectorWidth);
01496 
01497         // Go ahead and scalarize the two input vectors now.
01498         // FIXME: it's ok if some or all of the values of these two vectors
01499         // have undef values, so long as we don't try to access undef
01500         // values with the vector indices provided to the instruction.
01501         // Should fix lScalarizeVector so that it doesn't return false in
01502         // this case and just leaves the elements of the arrays with undef
01503         // values as NULL.
01504         llvm::Value *v0[ISPC_MAX_NVEC], *v1[ISPC_MAX_NVEC];
01505         if (!lScalarizeVector(svi->getOperand(0), v0) ||
01506             !lScalarizeVector(svi->getOperand(1), v1))
01507             return false;
01508 
01509         llvm::ConstantVector *shuffleIndicesVector = 
01510             llvm::dyn_cast<llvm::ConstantVector>(svi->getOperand(2));
01511         // I think this has to be a ConstantVector.  If this ever hits,
01512         // we'll dig into what we got instead and figure out how to handle
01513         // that...
01514         assert(shuffleIndicesVector != NULL);
01515 
01516         // Get the integer indices for each element of the returned vector
01517         llvm::SmallVector<llvm::Constant *, ISPC_MAX_NVEC> shuffleIndices;
01518         shuffleIndicesVector->getVectorElements(shuffleIndices);
01519         assert((int)shuffleIndices.size() == g->target.vectorWidth);
01520 
01521         // And loop over the indices, setting the i'th element of the
01522         // result vector with the source vector element that corresponds to
01523         // the i'th shuffle index value.
01524         for (unsigned int i = 0; i < shuffleIndices.size(); ++i) {
01525             if (!llvm::isa<llvm::ConstantInt>(shuffleIndices[i]))
01526                 // I'm not sure when this case would ever happen, though..
01527                 return false;
01528             int offset = (int)lGetIntValue(shuffleIndices[i]);
01529             assert(offset >= 0 && offset < n0+n1);
01530 
01531             if (offset < n0)
01532                 // Offsets from 0 to n0-1 index into the first vector
01533                 scalarizedVector[i] = v0[offset];
01534             else
01535                 // And offsets from n0 to (n0+n1-1) index into the second
01536                 // vector
01537                 scalarizedVector[i] = v1[offset - n0];
01538         }
01539         FATAL("the above code is untested so far; check now that it's actually running");
01540         return true;
01541     }
01542 
01543 #if 0
01544     fprintf(stderr, "flatten vector fixme\n");
01545     vec->dump();
01546     assert(0);
01547 #endif
01548 
01549     return false;
01550 }
01551 
01552 
01553 /** Conservative test to see if two values are equal.  There are
01554     (potentially many) cases where the two values actually are equal but
01555     this will return false.  However, if it does return true, the two
01556     vectors definitely are equal.  
01557 
01558     @todo This seems to catch all of the cases we currently need it for in
01559     practice, but it's be nice to make it a little more robust/general.  In
01560     general, though, a little something called the halting problem means we
01561     won't get all of them.
01562  */
01563 static bool
01564 lValuesAreEqual(llvm::Value *v0, llvm::Value *v1) {
01565     // Thanks to the fact that LLVM hashes and returns the same pointer for
01566     // constants (of all sorts, even constant expressions), this first test
01567     // actually catches a lot of cases.  LLVM's SSA form also helps a lot
01568     // with this..
01569     if (v0 == v1)
01570         return true;
01571 
01572     llvm::BinaryOperator *bo0 = llvm::dyn_cast<llvm::BinaryOperator>(v0);
01573     llvm::BinaryOperator *bo1 = llvm::dyn_cast<llvm::BinaryOperator>(v1);
01574     if (bo0 && bo1) {
01575         if (bo0->getOpcode() != bo1->getOpcode())
01576             return false;
01577         return (lValuesAreEqual(bo0->getOperand(0), bo1->getOperand(0)) &&
01578                 lValuesAreEqual(bo0->getOperand(1), bo1->getOperand(1)));
01579     }
01580 
01581     return false;
01582 }
01583 
01584 
01585 /** Tests to see if all of the llvm::Values in the array are equal.  Like
01586     lValuesAreEqual, this is a conservative test and may return false for
01587     arrays where the values are actually all equal.
01588  */
01589 static bool
01590 lVectorValuesAllEqual(llvm::Value *v[ISPC_MAX_NVEC]) {
01591     for (int i = 0; i < g->target.vectorWidth-1; ++i)
01592         if (!lValuesAreEqual(v[i], v[i+1]))
01593             return false;
01594     return true;
01595 }
01596 
01597 
01598 /** Given an array of scalar integer values, test to see if they are a
01599     linear sequence of compile-time constant integers starting from an
01600     arbirary value but then having a step of value "stride" between
01601     elements.
01602  */
01603 static bool
01604 lVectorIsLinearConstantInts(llvm::Value *v[ISPC_MAX_NVEC], int stride) {
01605     llvm::ConstantInt *prev = llvm::dyn_cast<llvm::ConstantInt>(v[0]);
01606     if (!prev)
01607         return false;
01608     int prevVal = (int)prev->getZExtValue();
01609 
01610     // For each element in the array, see if it is both a ConstantInt and
01611     // if the difference between it and the value of the previous element
01612     // is stride.  If not, fail.
01613     for (int i = 1; i < g->target.vectorWidth; ++i) {
01614         llvm::ConstantInt *next = llvm::dyn_cast<llvm::ConstantInt>(v[i]);
01615         if (!next) 
01616             return false;
01617 
01618         int nextVal = (int)next->getZExtValue();
01619         if (prevVal + stride != nextVal)
01620             return false;
01621 
01622         prevVal = nextVal;
01623     }
01624     return true;
01625 }
01626 
01627 
01628 /** Given an array of integer-typed values, see if the elements of the
01629     array have a step of 'stride' between their values.  This function
01630     tries to handle as many possibilities as possible, including things
01631     like all elements equal to some non-constant value plus an integer
01632     offset, etc.
01633 
01634     @todo FIXME Crazy thought: can we just build up expressions that
01635     subtract the constants [v[0], v[0]+stride, v[0]+2*stride, ...] from the
01636     given values, throw the LLVM optimizer at those, and then see if we get
01637     back an array of all zeros?
01638  */
01639 static bool
01640 lVectorIsLinear(llvm::Value *v[ISPC_MAX_NVEC], int stride) {
01641 #if 0
01642     lPrintVector("called lVectorIsLinear", v);
01643 #endif
01644 
01645     // First try the easy case: if the values are all just constant
01646     // integers and have the expected stride between them, then we're done.
01647     if (lVectorIsLinearConstantInts(v, stride))
01648         return true;
01649 
01650     // ConstantExprs need a bit of deconstruction to figure out
01651 
01652     // FIXME: do we need to handle cases where e.g. v[0] is an
01653     // llvm::ConstantInt and then the rest are ConstExprs??
01654     if (llvm::dyn_cast<llvm::ConstantExpr>(v[0])) {
01655         // First, see if all of the array elements are ConstantExprs of
01656         // some sort.  If not, give up.
01657         // FIXME: are we potentially missing cases here, e.g. a mixture of
01658         // ConstantExprs and ConstantInts?
01659         for (int i = 0; i < g->target.vectorWidth; ++i) {
01660             if (!llvm::isa<llvm::ConstantExpr>(v[i]))
01661                 return false;
01662         }
01663 
01664         // See if any of the array elements are adds of constant
01665         // expressions.  As it turns out, LLVM's constant expression
01666         // optimizer is very thorough about converting "add(0, foo)" to
01667         // "foo", so we need to deal with cases where element 0 is "foo",
01668         // element 1 is add(4, foo), etc...
01669         bool anyAdds = false, allAdds = true;
01670         for (int i = 0; i < g->target.vectorWidth; ++i) {
01671             llvm::ConstantExpr *ce = llvm::dyn_cast<llvm::ConstantExpr>(v[i]);
01672             if (ce->getOpcode() == llvm::Instruction::Add)
01673                 anyAdds = true;
01674             else 
01675                 allAdds = false;
01676         }
01677 
01678         if (anyAdds && !allAdds) {
01679             // In v[], we should have an array of elements that are all
01680             // either ConstExprs with add operators, where one of the
01681             // operads is a constant int, or other non-add ConstExpr
01682             // values.  
01683             // 
01684             // Now we through each element and:
01685             // 1. For ones that aren't add ConstExprs, treat them as if they 
01686             //    are an add with 0 as the other operand.
01687             // 2. Extract the ConstInt operand of the add into the intBit[]
01688             //    array and put the other operand in the otherBit[] array.
01689             llvm::Value *intBit[ISPC_MAX_NVEC], *otherBit[ISPC_MAX_NVEC];
01690             for (int i = 0; i < g->target.vectorWidth; ++i) {
01691                 llvm::ConstantExpr *ce = llvm::dyn_cast<llvm::ConstantExpr>(v[i]);
01692                 if (ce->getOpcode() == llvm::Instruction::Add) {
01693                     // The ConstantInt may be either of the two operands of
01694                     // the add.  Put the operands in the right arrays.
01695                     if (llvm::isa<llvm::ConstantInt>(ce->getOperand(0))) {
01696                         intBit[i] = ce->getOperand(0);
01697                         otherBit[i] = ce->getOperand(1);
01698                     }
01699                     else {
01700                         intBit[i] = ce->getOperand(1);
01701                         otherBit[i] = ce->getOperand(0);
01702                     }
01703                 }
01704                 else {
01705                     // We don't have an Add, so pretend we have an add with
01706                     // zero.
01707                     intBit[i] = LLVMInt32(0);
01708                     otherBit[i] = v[i];
01709                 }
01710             }
01711 
01712             // Now that everything is lined up, see if we have a case where
01713             // we're adding constant values with the desired stride to the
01714             // same base value.  If so, we know we have a linear set of
01715             // locations.
01716             return (lVectorIsLinear(intBit, stride) &&
01717                     lVectorValuesAllEqual(otherBit));
01718         }
01719 
01720         // If this ever hits, the assertion can just be commented out and
01721         // false returned below.  However, it's worth figuring out how the
01722         // analysis needs to be generalized rather than necessarily giving
01723         // up and possibly hurting performance of the final code.
01724         FATAL("Unexpected case with a ConstantExpr in lVectorIsLinear");
01725 #if 0
01726         for (int i = 0; i < g->target.vectorWidth; ++i)
01727             v[i]->dump();
01728         FATAL("FIXME");
01729 #endif
01730         return false;
01731     }
01732 
01733 
01734     llvm::BinaryOperator *bop = llvm::dyn_cast<llvm::BinaryOperator>(v[0]);
01735     if (bop) {
01736         // We also need to deal with non-constant binary operators that
01737         // represent linear accesses here..
01738         // FIXME: here, too, what about cases with v[0] being a load or something
01739         // and then everything after element 0 being a binary operator with an add.
01740         // That won't get caught by this case??
01741         bool anyAdd = false;
01742         for (int i = 0; i < g->target.vectorWidth; ++i) {
01743             llvm::BinaryOperator *bopi = llvm::dyn_cast<llvm::BinaryOperator>(v[i]);
01744             if (bopi && bopi->getOpcode() == llvm::Instruction::Add)
01745                 anyAdd = true;
01746         }
01747 
01748         if (anyAdd) {
01749             // is one of the operands the same for all elements?  if so, then just
01750             // need to check this case for the other operand...
01751 
01752             // FIXME: do we need a more general check that starts with both
01753             // the first and second operand of v[0]'s add and then checks
01754             // the remainder of the elements to see if either one of their
01755             // two operands matches the one we started with?  That would be
01756             // more robust to switching the ordering of operands, in case
01757             // that ever happens...
01758             for (int operand = 0; operand <= 1; ++operand) {
01759                 llvm::Value *addOperandValues[ISPC_MAX_NVEC];
01760                 // Go through the vector elements and grab the operand'th
01761                 // one if this is an add or the v
01762                 for (int i = 0; i < g->target.vectorWidth; ++i) {
